content: The "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996" aims to protect citizens from armed violent criminals by focusing on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating offenders to prevent them from quickly returning to the streets. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force considers severe punishment, laws on apprehension and prosecution, available resources, and the nature of violent crime. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force considers the effectiveness of Federal and State laws, resources available to law enforcement agencies, the nature of violent crime in the district, and limited Federal involvement in prosecution. The Attorney General requires monthly reports on defendants charged with violating specific laws and biannual compilations submitted to Congress. Additionally, United States attorneys have the authority to request waivers from the Attorney General regarding certain requirements. The Attorney General must establish guidelines for subsection (a) requests, considering the number of assistant US attorneys and level of violent crime. An armed violent criminal is defined as someone accused of violating specific laws. This section expires after 5 years from the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF THE PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO SEMIAUTOMATIC ASSAULT WEAPONS AND LARGE CAPACITY AMMUNITION FEEDING DEVICES. Amends various sections of title 18, United States Code, to repeal prohibitions on certain firearms and ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 5. MANDATORY PRISON TERMS FOR POSSESSING, BRANDISHING, OR DISCHARGING A FIREARM OR DESTRUCTIVE DEVICE DURING A FEDERAL CRIME THAT IS A CRIME OF VIOLENCE OR A DRUG TRAFFICKING CRIME. Introduces mandatory prison terms for specific firearm-related offenses during federal crimes of violence or drug trafficking. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The sentences range from 5 years for possession to 20 years for discharging a firearm with the intent to injure another person. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The sentences range from 5 years for possession to 20 years for discharging a firearm with the intent to injure another person. For subsequent convictions, additional sentences of 10 to 30 years apply depending on the type of firearm involved. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. For subsequent convictions, additional sentences of 20 to 30 years apply depending on the actions taken with the firearm. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. For subsequent convictions, additional sentences of 30 years to life imprisonment apply, with restrictions on probation and concurrent sentences. Passed the House of Representatives on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
